heading: Welcome to SER!
text:
open source, reproducible vignette accompanies half-day workshop 
modern methods causal mediation analysis, given SER 2021
Meeting Monday, 24 May 2021. encourage use bookdown
site, convenience, also made workshop materials available 
PDF.

heading: 0.1 About this workshop
text:
Causal mediation analysis can provide mechanistic understanding 
exposure impacts outcome, central goal epidemiology health sciences.
However, rapid methodologic developments coupled formal courses
presents challenges implementation. Beginning overview classical
direct indirect effects, workshop present recent advances 
overcome limitations previous methods, allowing : () continuous
exposures, (ii) multiple, non-independent mediators, (iii) effects
identifiable presence intermediate confounders affected exposure.
Emphasis placed flexible, stochastic interventional direct 
indirect effects, highlighting may applied answer substantive
epidemiological questions real-world studies. Multiply robust,
nonparametric estimators causal effects, free open source R
packages (medshift 
medoutcon) application, 
introduced.ensure translation real-world data analysis, workshop 
incorporate hands-R programming exercises allow participants practice 
implementing statistical tools presented. recommended 
participants working knowledge basic notions causal inference,
including counterfactuals identification (linking causal effect 
parameter estimable observed data distribution). Familiarity 
R programming language also recommended.

text:
10:00A-10:30A: introductions/mediation set up10:30A-11:00A: estimands choose11:00A-11:30A: discussion: choose real-world examples11:30A-12:00P: shift parameter introduction application lecture part12:00P-12:15P break/discussion12:15P-12:45P estimation natural direct indirect effects,
interventional direct indirect effects12:45P-01:15P: practice R code estimation01:15P-01:30P: estimation stochastic interventional direct indirect
effects01:30P-01:50P: practice: code estimation01:50P-02:00P wrap upNOTE: times listed Pacific Time.

heading: 2.2 Natural direct and indirect effects
text:
Natural direct effect (NDE):
\[  \psi_{\text{NDE}} = \E(Y_{1,M_0}) - \E(Y_{0,M_0}) \]Natural indirect effect (NIE):
\[
  \psi_{\text{NIE}} = \E(Y_{1,M_1}) - \E(Y_{1,M_0})
\]NDE can also written : \(\E_W \sum_m \{\E(Y_{1,m} \mid W) - \E(Y_{0,m} \mid W)\} \P(M_{0}=m \mid W)\)Weighted average controlled direct effects level \(m\).interaction \(\) \(M\) \(Y\), CDE = NDE.

chapter: 3 The Interventional Direct and Indirect Effects
heading: 3.1.3 Recovering direct and indirect effects
text:
Even though estimation NDE NIE possible 
presence confounders mediation-outcome relation affected 
treatment, possible redefine effects way 
identifiable. Specifically:Let \(G()\) denote random draw distribution \(M() \mid W\)Define counterfactual \(Y(1,G(0))\) counterfactual
variable hypothetical world \(\) set \(=1\) \(M\) 
set \(M=G(0)\) porbability one.Define \(Y(0,G(0))\) \(Y(1,G(1))\) similarlyThen can define:
\[\begin{equation*}
  \E[Y(1,G(1)) - Y(0,G(0))] = \underbrace{\E[Y(1,G(1)) -
    Y(1,G(0))]}_{\text{interventional indirect effect}} +
    \underbrace{\E[Y(1,G(0)) -
    Y(0,G(0))]}_{\text{interventional direct effect}}
\end{equation*}\]

text:

\[NIE = E(Y_{1,M_{1}}) - E(Y_{1,M_{0}})\].

text:
\(O=(W, , M, Y)\)SCM represented DAG following causal models:

mediator. restrictions distribution \(W\) \(Y\).Recall need assume following identify caual effects

heading: 6.1.2 How to estimate using G-computation
text:
Let’s take NDE example:Fit regression \(Y\) \(M,,W\). Predict outcome values setting \(=1\).
’ll call result \(\bar{Q}_Y(M,1,W)\). Predict outcome values setting
\(=0\). ’ll call result \(\bar{Q}_Y(M,0,W)\).Take difference \(\bar{Q}_Y(M,1,W) - \bar{Q}_Y(M,0,W)\) regress 
\(W\) among \(=0\). recovers expected difference 
individuals set control condition \(= 0\).sample mean predicted values gives estimate.

6.1.4 How to estimate using TMLE
text:
Estimate
\[\begin{equation*}
 C_Y(Q_M, g)(O) = \Bigg\{\frac{\(= 1)}{g(1 \mid W)}
   \frac{Q_M(M \mid 0, W)}{Q_M(M \mid 1, W)} -
   \frac{\(= 0)}{g(0 \mid W)} \Bigg\}.
  \end{equation*}\]
Breaking , \(\frac{\(= 1)}{g(1 \mid W)}\) inverse probability
weight \(= 1\) , likewise, \(\frac{\(= 0)}{g(0 \mid W)}\) inverse
probability weight \(= 0\). middle term ratio mediator
density \(= 0\) mediator density \(= 1\).Estimating \(Q_M\) really hard problem \(M\) high-dimensional. ,
since ratio conditional densitities, can reparamterize
using Bayes rule get something easier compute:
\[\begin{equation*}
  \frac{\P(= 0 \mid M, W) g(0 \mid W)}{\P(= 1 \mid M, W) g(1 \mid W)}.
\end{equation*}\]Underneath hood, counterfactual outcome difference
\(\bar{Q}_{\text{diff}}\) \(P(\mid Z, W)\), conditional probability \(\)
given \(Z\) \(W\), used constructing auxiliary covariate TML
estimation. nuisance parameters play important role 
bias-correcting TMLE-update step.estimate \(g_{\mid W}(W)=P(=\mid W)\) logistic regression 
\(\) \(W\), generating predicted probabilities \(=1\) \(g(1 \mid W)\)
\(=0\) \(g(0 \mid W)\).estimate \(\P(=\mid M, W)\) logistic regression \(\) \(M, W\),
generating predicted probabilities \(=1\) \(=0\).\(\bar{Q}_Y(M,^\prime,W) - \bar{Q}_Y(M,^\star,W)\)obtain estimate \(\bar{Q}_{diff} = \bar{Q}_Y(M,1,W) - \bar{Q}_Y(M,0,W)\), predict values \(Y\) regression \(Y\) \(M,,W\),
setting \(=1\) \(=0\), giving \(\hat{Y}(m, 1, w)\) \(\hat{Y}(m, 1, w)\).Estimate \(\hat{\epsilon}\) setting \(\epsilon\) intercept 
weighted logistic regression model \(Y\) 
\(logit(\hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(M,,W))\) offset weights \(\hat{C}_{Y}\).Estimate \(\hat{\epsilon}\) setting \(\epsilon\) intercept 
weighted logistic regression model \(Y\) 
\(logit(\hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(M,,W))\) offset weights \(\hat{C}_{Y}\).estimates \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,1,W)\) \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,0,W)\) updated
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{Y}(M,,W) = \hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(\epsilon_n)(M,,W)\). gives updated difference:
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{diff}(M,,W)\).estimates \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,1,W)\) \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,0,W)\) updated
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{Y}(M,,W) = \hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(\epsilon_n)(M,,W)\). gives updated difference:
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{diff}(M,,W)\).regress \(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{diff}(M,,W)\) \(W\) among 
\(=0\). Taking empirical mean predicted values gives us 
TML estimate NDE.
code:
amodel <- "a ~ w "
mmodel <- "m ~ a + w"
amodel <- "a ~ m + w"
ymodel <- "y ~ m + a*w"

# make gm
afit <- glm(formula = amodel, family = "binomial", data = obsdat)
mfit <- glm(formula = mmodel, family = "binomial", data = obsdat)

a1 <- predict(afit, newdata = data.frame(w = obsdat$w), type = "response")
a0 <- 1 - a1

am1 <- predict(amfit,
  newdata = data.frame(w = obsdat$w, m = obsdat$m),
  type = "response"
)
am0 <- 1 - am1
cy <- (am0 * a0) / (am1 * a1)
qyinit <- cbind(
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, a = a, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, a, m)), type = "response"
  ),
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, a = a, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, a = 0, m)), type = "response"
  ),
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, a = 1, m)), type = "response"
  )
)

qbardiff <- qyinit[, 3] - qyinit[, 2]
epsilon <- coef(glm(y ~ 1,
  weights = cy, offset = (qlogis(qyinit[, 1])),
  family = "quasibinomial"
))
qyupa0 <- plogis(qlogis(qyinit[, 2]) + epsilon)
qyupa1 <- plogis(qlogis(qyinit[, 3]) + epsilon)
qdiffup <- qyupa1 - qyupa0
margqdiff_fit <- glm(qdiffup ~ w,
  data = data.frame(
    qdiffup = qdiffup[a == 0],
    w = w[a == 0]
  )
)
margqdiff <- predict(margqdiff_fit,
  newdata = data.frame(qdiffup = qdiffup, w = w)
)
tmlende <- mean(margqdiff)

heading: 6.2 Interventional direct and indirect effects
text:
Recall:define interventional direct effect :
\[\begin{equation*}
  \psi_{\text{PIDE}} = \E(Y_{^\prime,g_{M \mid ^\star,W}}) -
    \E(Y_{\star,g_{M \mid ^\star,W}}),
\end{equation*}\]
interventional indirect effect :
\[\begin{equation*}
  \psi_{\text{PIIE}} = \E(Y_{^\prime,g_{M \mid ^\prime,W}}) -
    \E(Y_{^\prime,g_{M \mid ^\star,W}}).
\end{equation*}\]

heading: 6.3 Simple case for intuition
text:
Consider simple data structure \(O=(W, , Z, M, Y)\). SCM represented 
DAG following causal models:
\[\begin{align*}
  W &= f(U_W)\\
  &= f(U_A)\\
  Z &= f(, W, U_Z)\\
  M &= f(Z, , W, U_M)\\
  Y &= f(M, Z, , W, U_Y),
\end{align*}\]
(\(U_W, U_A, U_Z, U_M, U_Y\)) exogenous random errors. assume \(\) 
single binary treatment, \(Z\) single binary intermediate confounder, \(M\)
single binary mediator. restrictions distribution 
\(W\) \(Y\).\(g_{M \mid ^\prime,W}\) represents stochastic draw counterfactual,
conditional distribution \(M\), described 
VanderWeele (2016):
\[\begin{equation*}
  g_{M \mid ,W}(m, ^{\star}, W) \equiv g_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}(W) =
    \sum_{z=0}^1 \P(M=1 \mid Z=z,W) \P(Z=z \mid =^{\star}, W).
\end{equation*}\]
follows, going assume \(g_{M \mid ,W}(m, ^{\star}, W)\)
known, estimated observed data, call
\(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}\). going slightly alter usual
identification assumptions longer need assume exchangeability
\(\) counterfactual \(M\) values. means remaining assumptions
controlled direct effects.

heading: 6.3.1 Estimation using G-Computation
text:
estimand \(E(Y_{^\prime, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^\star,W}})\) can identified
via sequential regression, provides framework 
G-computation-based estimator. procedure followsFit regression \(Y\) \(M,Z,W\). Predict outcome values 
\(M=m\). ’ll call result \(\bar{Q}_Y(M,Z,W)\).Integrate \(M\) stochastic intervention
\(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}\). can evaluating
\(\E(Y \mid M=m,Z=z,W)\) \(m\) multiplying probability
\(M=m\) \(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}\), summing \(m\).
’ll call results \(\bar{Q}^{g}_M(Z,W)\).Integrate \(Z\) set \(=^\prime\). , can evaluating
predicted values Step 2, setting \(=^\prime\), \(z\),
multiplying prediction probability \(Z=z\) \(=^\prime\).
’ll call result \(\bar{Q}^{^\prime}_Z(W)\).Taking sample mean (marginalizing \(W\)) gives parameter
estimate.

heading: 6.3.2 Estimate with doubly robust methods based on the EIF
text:
EIF parameter \(\Psi(P)(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star},W})\),
, , \(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}\) assumed known, given :
\[\begin{align*}
  D^{\star}(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) &= \sum_{k=0}^2
      D_k^{\star}(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}), \text{ }\\
  D^{\star}_0(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) &=
      \bar{Q}^{^{\prime}}_{Z(W)} -
      \Psi(P)(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W})\\
  D^{\star}_1(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) &=
      \frac{(=^{\prime})}{\P(=^{\prime} \mid W)}(\bar{Q}^{\hat{g}}_M(Z,W)
      - \bar{Q}^{^{\prime}}_{Z(W)})\\
  D^{\star}_2(^{\prime}, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) &=
      \frac{(=^{\prime})\{(M=1) \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W} +
      (M=0)(1-\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) \}}{\P(=^{\prime}}
      &\times (Y-\bar{Q}_{Y(M,Z,W)}).
\end{align*}\]

heading: 6.3.3 Estimate using TMLE
text:
estimate \(g_{Z \mid ^{\star}, W}(W) = \P(Z=1 \mid =^{\star}, W)\) 
logistic regression \(Z\) \(, W\) setting \(=^{\star}\).estimate \(g_{M \mid z,W}(W) = \P(M=1 \mid Z=z, W)\) logistic
regression \(M\) \(Z, W\), setting \(z=\{0,1\}\).use quantities calculate \(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W} = \hat{g}_{M \mid z=1,W}\hat{g}_{Z \mid ^{\star}, W} + \hat{g}_{M \mid z=0,W}(1-\hat{g}_{Z|^{\star}, W})\).obtain estimate \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,Z,W)\), predict values \(Y\) 
regression \(Y\) \(M,Z,W\), setting \(m=1\) \(m=0\), giving
\(\hat{Y}(m=1, z, w)\) \(\hat{Y}(m=0, z, w)\).Estimate weights used initial targeting step:
\[\begin{equation*}
   h_1() = \frac{(=)\{(M=1)\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W} +
     (M=0)(1-\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) \}}{\P(=)\{(M=1)
     g_{M \mid Z,W} + (M=0)(1-g_{M \mid Z,W}) \}}
\end{equation*}\]Estimate \(\hat{\epsilon}\) setting \(\epsilon\) intercept 
weighted logistic regression model \(Y\) 
\(\text{logit}(\hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(M,Z,W))\) offset weights
\(\hat{h}_{1}()\). (Note just one possible TMLE.)Estimate \(\hat{\epsilon}\) setting \(\epsilon\) intercept 
weighted logistic regression model \(Y\) 
\(\text{logit}(\hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(M,Z,W))\) offset weights
\(\hat{h}_{1}()\). (Note just one possible TMLE.)estimate \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,Z,W)\) updated 
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{Y}(M,Z,W) = \hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(\epsilon_n)(M,Z,W)\).estimate \(\bar{Q}_{Y}(M,Z,W)\) updated 
\(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{\star}_{Y}(M,Z,W) = \hat{\bar{Q}}_{Y}(\epsilon_n)(M,Z,W)\).next integrate \(M\) \(\bar{Q}^{\star}_{Y}(M,Z,W)\). First, 
estimate \(\bar{Q}^{\star}_{Y,n}(M,Z,W)\) setting \(m=1\) \(m=0\), giving
\(\bar{Q}^{\star}_Y(m=1, z, w)\) \(\bar{Q}^{\star}_Y(m=0, z, w)\). ,
multiply predicted values probabilities 
\(\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star},W}(W)\) (\(\\{, ^{\star}\}\)), add
together (.e., \(\bar{Q}^{\hat{g}}_{M,n}(Z,W) = \hat{Q}^{\star}_Y(m=1, z, w) \hat{g}_{M|^{\star},W} + \hat{Q}^{\star}_Y(m=0, z, w)(1-\hat{g}_{M|^{\star},W})\)).now fit regression \(\bar{Q}^{\hat{g},\star}_{M,n}(Z,W)\) \(W\)
among \(=^\prime\). call predicted values 
regression \(\hat{\bar{Q}}^{^\prime}_{Z}(W)\).(Note \(\) randomly assigned, need complete 
second targeting step.)empirical mean predicted values TML estimate 
\(\Psi(P)(^\prime, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W})\).Repeat steps interventions. example, 
binary \(\), execute steps total three times 
estimate:
\(\Psi(P)(1,\hat{g}_{M \mid 1, W})\),
\(\Psi(P)(1,\hat{g}_{M \mid 0, W})\), 
\(\Psi(P)(0,\hat{g}_{M \mid 0, W})\).
\(\Psi(P)(1,\hat{g}_{M \mid 1, W})\),\(\Psi(P)(1,\hat{g}_{M \mid 0, W})\), \(\Psi(P)(0,\hat{g}_{M \mid 0, W})\).PIDE can obtained substituting estimates parameters
\(\Psi(P)(,\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W}) - \Psi(P)(^{\star},\hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W})\) PIIE
can obtained substituting estimates parameters
\(\Psi(P)(,\hat{g}_{M \mid ,W}) - \Psi(P)(, \hat{g}_{M \mid ^{\star}, W})\).variance can estimated sample variance EIF (defined
, substituting targeted fits) divided \(n\).
code:
zmodel <- "z ~ a + w1 "
mmodel <- "m ~ z + w1"
ymodel <- "y ~ m + z*w1"

# make gm and get counterfactual predictions
zfit <- glm(formula = zmodel, family = "binomial", data = obsdat)
mfit <- glm(formula = mmodel, family = "binomial", data = obsdat)

za0 <- predict(zfit,
  newdata = data.frame(w1 = obsdat$w1, a = 0),
  type = "response"
)
za1 <- predict(zfit,
  newdata = data.frame(w1 = obsdat$w1, a = 1),
  type = "response"
)

mz1 <- predict(mfit,
  newdata = data.frame(w1 = obsdat$w1, z = 1),
  type = "response"
)
mz0 < -predict(mfit,
  newdata = data.frame(w1 = obsdat$w1, z = 0),
  type = "response"
)

gm0 <- (mz1 * za0) + (mz0 * (1 - za0))
gma1 <- (mz1 * za1) + (mz0 * (1 - za1))
tmpdat$qyinit <- cbind(
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m)), type = "response"
  ),
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = 0)), type = "response"
  ),
  predict(glm(
    formula = ymodel, family = "binomial",
    data = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m, y = y))
  ),
  newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = 1)), type = "response"
  )
)
psa1 <- I(a == 1) / mean(a)
psa0 <- I(a == 0) / mean(1 - a)
mz <- predict(glm(
  formula = mmodel, family = "binomial",
  data = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z, m = m))
),
newdata = data.frame(cbind(datw, z = z)), type = "response"
)
psm <- (mz * m) + ((1 - mz) * (1 - m))

tmpdat$ha1gma1 <- ((m * gma1 + (1 - m) * (1 - gma1)) / psm) * psa1 * svywt
tmpdat$ha1gma0 <- ((m * gm + (1 - m) * (1 - gm)) / psm) * psa1 * svywt
tmpdat$ha0gma0 <- ((m * gm + (1 - m) * (1 - gm)) / psm) * psa0 * svywt
# for E(Y_{1,gmastar})
epsilonma1g0 <- coef(glm(y ~ 1,
  weights = tmpdat$ha1gma0,
  offset = (qlogis(qyinit[, 1])),
  family = "quasibinomial", data = tmpdat
))
tmpdat$qyupm0a1g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 2]) + epsilonma1g0)
tmpdat$qyupm1a1g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 3]) + epsilonma1g0)

# for E(Y_{1,gma})
epsilonma1g1 <- coef(glm(y ~ 1,
  weights = tmpdat$ha1gma1,
  offset = (qlogis(qyinit[, 1])),
  family = "quasibinomial", data = tmpdat
))
tmpdat$qyupm0a1g1 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 2]) + epsilonma1g1)
tmpdat$qyupm1a1g1 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 3]) + epsilonma1g1)

# for E(Y_{0,gmastar})
epsilonma0g0 <- coef(glm(y ~ 1,
  weights = tmpdat$ha0gma0,
  offset = (qlogis(qyinit[, 1])),
  family = "quasibinomial", data = tmpdat
))
tmpdat$qyupm0a0g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 2]) + epsilonma0g0)
tmpdat$qyupm1a0g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 3]) + epsilonma0g0)
tmpdat$Qma1g0 <- tmpdat$qyupm0a1g0 * (1 - gm) + tmpdat$qyupm1a1g0 * gm
tmpdat$Qma1g1 <- tmpdat$qyupm0a1g1 * (1 - gma1) + tmpdat$qyupm1a1g1 * gma1
tmpdat$Qma0g0 <- tmpdat$qyupm0a0g0 * (1 - gm) + tmpdat$qyupm1a0g0 * gm
Qzfita1g0 <- glm(
  formula = paste("Qma1g0", qmodel, sep = "~"),
  data = tmpdat[tmpdat$a == 1, ], family = "quasibinomial"
)
Qzfita1g1 <- glm(
  formula = paste("Qma1g1", qmodel, sep = "~"),
  data = tmpdat[tmpdat$a == 1, ], family = "quasibinomial"
)
Qzfita0g0 <- glm(
  formula = paste("Qma0g0", qmodel, sep = "~"),
  data = tmpdat[tmpdat$a == 0, ], family = "quasibinomial"
)

Qza1g0 <- predict(Qzfita1g0, type = "response", newdata = tmpdat)
Qza1g1 <- predict(Qzfita1g1, type = "response", newdata = tmpdat)
Qza0g0 <- predict(Qzfita0g0, type = "response", newdata = tmpdat)
tmlea1m0 <- sum(Qzupa1g0 * svywt) / sum(svywt)
tmlea1m1 <- sum(Qzupa1g1 * svywt) / sum(svywt)
tmlea0m0 <- sum(Qzupa0g0 * svywt) / sum(svywt)
nde <- tmlea1m0 - tmlea0m0
nie <- tmlea1m1 - tmlea1m0
# first get EIF
tmpdat$qyupa1g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 1]) + epsilonma1g0)
tmpdat$qyupa1g1 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 1]) + epsilonma1g1)
tmpdat$qyupa0g0 <- plogis(qlogis(tmpdat$qyinit[, 1]) + epsilonma0g0)

eic1a1g0 <- tmpdat$ha1gma0 * (tmpdat$y - tmpdat$qyupa1g0)
eic2a1g0 <- psa1 * svywt * (tmpdat$Qma1g0 - Qzupa1g0)
eic3a1g0 <- Qzupa1g0 - tmlea1m0
eica1g0 <- eic1a1g0 + eic2a1g0 + eic3a1g0

eic1a1g1 <- tmpdat$ha1gma1 * (tmpdat$y - tmpdat$qyupa1g1)
eic2a1g1 <- psa1 * svywt * (tmpdat$Qma1g1 - Qzupa1g1)
eic3a1g1 <- Qzupa1g1 - tmlea1m1
eica1g1 <- eic1a1g1 + eic2a1g1 + eic3a1g1

eic1a0g0 <- tmpdat$ha0gma0 * (tmpdat$y - tmpdat$qyupa0g0)
eic2a0g0 <- psa0 * svywt * (tmpdat$Qma0g0 - Qzupa0g0)
eic3a0g0 <- Qzupa0g0 - tmlea0m0
eica0g0 <- eic1a0g0 + eic2a0g0 + eic3a0g0

# estimands
ndeeic <- eica1g0 - eica0g0
vareic <- var(ndeeic) / nrow(tmpdat)

nieeic <- eica1g1 - eica1g0
varnieeic <- var(nieeic) / nrow(tmpdat)

heading: 6.4 The general case
text:
Actually, want fixed parameter true, unknown
\(g_{M \mid , W}\) like \(M\) continuous/multi-dimensional.pain hand, Nima made easy--use package us
called medoutcon! go
